name: MediaObject
description: A media object, such as an image, video, or audio object embedded in a web page or a downloadable dataset i.e. DataDownload. Note that a creative work may have many media objects associated with it on the same web page. For example, a page about a single song (MusicRecording) may have a music video (VideoObject), and a high and low bandwidth audio stream (2 AudioObject's).
title: MediaObject

fields.name: startTime
fields.title: startTime
fields.description: The startTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to start. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from January to December. For media, including audio and video, it's the time offset of the start of a clip within a larger file.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.

fields.name: uploadDate
fields.title: uploadDate
fields.description: Date when this media object was uploaded to this site.

fields.name: playerType
fields.title: playerType
fields.description: Player type requiredâ€”for example, Flash or Silverlight.

fields.name: bitrate
fields.title: bitrate
fields.description: The bitrate of the media object.

fields.name: requiresSubscription
fields.title: requiresSubscription
fields.description: Indicates if use of the media require a subscription  (either paid or free). Allowed values are true or false (note that an earlier version had 'yes', 'no').

fields.name: regionsAllowed
fields.title: regionsAllowed
fields.description: The regions where the media is allowed. If not specified, then it's assumed to be allowed everywhere. Specify the countries in ISO 3166 format.

fields.name: endTime
fields.title: endTime
fields.description: The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from January to December. For media, including audio and video, it's the time offset of the end of a clip within a larger file.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.

fields.name: embedUrl
fields.title: embedUrl
fields.description: A URL pointing to a player for a specific video. In general, this is the information in the src element of an embed tag and should not be the same as the content of the loc tag.

fields.name: contentUrl
fields.title: contentUrl
fields.description: Actual bytes of the media object, for example the image file or video file.

fields.name: associatedArticle
fields.title: associatedArticle
fields.description: A NewsArticle associated with the Media Object.

fields.name: productionCompany
fields.title: productionCompany
fields.description: The production company or studio responsible for the item e.g. series, video game, episode etc.

fields.name: duration
fields.title: duration
fields.description: The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.

fields.name: encodesCreativeWork
fields.title: encodesCreativeWork
fields.description: The CreativeWork encoded by this media object.

fields.name: encodingFormat
fields.title: encodingFormat
fields.description: Media type typically expressed using a MIME format (see IANA site and MDN reference) e.g. application/zip for a SoftwareApplication binary, audio/mpeg for .mp3 etc.).In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, encoding can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular encodingFormat information.Unregistered or niche encoding and file formats can be indicated instead via the most appropriate URL, e.g. defining Web page or a Wikipedia/Wikidata entry.
